#FacialRecognition cameras in #Cardiff snatched Ed‚Äôs biometric data twice ‚Äì once when shopping, and again when exercising his right to peaceful protest. We're in court with Ed to end unlawful police use of facial rec across the UK. It has no place in a rights-respecting democracy https://t.co/RM6k1TIJrY

South Wales Police has been at the forefront of #FacialRecognition use in the UK, receiving Government funding for it and using the tech in public on more than 50 occasions so far ‚Äì including scanning Ed Bridges twice. https://t.co/eIXRTXjOVi

Last week the city of San Francisco ‚Äì so often at the heart of technology advancement ‚Äì banned police use of #FacialRecognition ‚Äúto prevent the unleashing of this dangerous technology against the public‚Äù https://t.co/rJfm0H46Ah

Research has shown #FacialRecognition is more likely to misidentify women and people from minority ethnic groups - meaning they are more likely to be stopped and questioned by police, entrenching social bias. https://t.co/KckNNL7kHp

Without your consent, and often without your knowledge, #FacialRecognition cameras scan everyone who goes by, snatching deeply personal biometric data - a clear breach of your right to privacy. https://t.co/79AXMsgpE4

The biometric maps made by #FacialRecognition cameras are then matched against watch lists the police put together. These lists can include entirely innocent people. In 2017, the tech was used to target people with mental health conditions. https://t.co/X3FJfTarIi

#FacialRecognition cameras are light-years away from regular CCTV. They scan everyone within range and make unique biometric maps of their faces - more like a fingerprint than a photograph. https://t.co/9pdZHmlmok

The first-ever UK court case against police use of #FacialRecognition tech on our streets starts tomorrow.

South Wales Police has used the rights-abusing, discriminatory tech on the public over 50 times. We‚Äôre going to put an end to it.
